title: 114_hr3744
content: The Act may be cited as the "Venezuelan Refugee Assistance Act" and involves the adjustment of status for certain Venezuelan nationals. The "Venezuelan Refugee Assistance Act" allows for the adjustment of status to lawful permanent residence for eligible Venezuelan nationals if they apply before January 1, 2019 and meet specific criteria regarding admissibility and deportability. The criteria for adjustment of status to lawful permanent residence for eligible Venezuelan nationals include not participating in persecution based on certain criteria and not having certain criminal convictions. Alien present in the United States under removal orders may apply for adjustment of status without needing to file a motion to reopen. If the application is granted, the removal order will be canceled; if denied, the order remains enforceable. Aliens from Venezuela present in the US since January 1, 2013, for at least 1 year can apply for adjustment of status. The Secretary of Homeland Security can provide regulations for aliens with final removal orders to seek a stay based on filing an application. The Secretary of Homeland Security can authorize aliens from Venezuela in the US since January 1, 2013, to apply for adjustment of status. In removal proceedings, aliens can raise eligibility for adjustment of status as a defense, except if the application is denied. The Secretary may allow employment for aliens applying for adjustment of status. The Secretary of Homeland Security can authorize aliens from Venezuela in the US to apply for adjustment of status, allowing employment during the application process. Spouses and children can also have their status adjusted to lawful permanent residence under certain conditions. The alien can apply for adjustment of status to become a lawful permanent resident if they meet certain criteria, including being physically present in the US for at least 1 year, applying for adjustment while in the US, and meeting other eligibility requirements for an immigrant visa. The exclusion specified in certain paragraphs of the Immigration and Nationality Act does not apply. For establishing continuous physical presence, absences totaling up to 180 days are allowed. Applicants for adjustment of status have the right to administrative review. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for adjustment of status for certain aliens, with final decisions made by the Secretary of Homeland Security and no judicial review. The granting of permanent residence status does not affect the number of immigrant visas available. The Act's provisions apply unless specified otherwise. The Immigration and Nationality Act provisions apply to the administration of this Act, without affecting the Secretary of Homeland Security's authority in immigration enforcement. Eligibility for permanent residence status under this Act does not prevent an alien from seeking such status under other laws.
